name: Avoid storing passwords in the config files
description: Storing passwords, in a config files is something to be avoided at all costs.
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in config file
rationale: Failure frequently compromises all data that should have been protected. Typically, this information includes sensitive personal information (PII) data such as health records, credentials, personal data, and credit cards, which often require protection as defined by laws or regulations such as the EU GDPR or local privacy laws.
reference:
CWE-260: Password in Configuration File
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/260.html

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10-2017_A6-Security_Misconfiguration

A6-Security_Misconfiguration
remediation: Username and password information should not be included in a configuration file or a properties file in plaintext as this will allow anyone who can read the file access to the resource. If possible, encrypt this information
remediationSample:
We should not store user information in the connection string. We should either use the trusted connection or use verious avilable encryption algo to encrypt the connection string 

more details are available about different security @ https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/data/adonet/connection-string-syntax
sample:
<connectionStrings>
<add name="ud_DEV" connectionString="connectDB=uDB; uid=db2admin; pwd=password; dbalias=uDB;" providerName="System.Data.Odbc" />
</connectionStrings>
...
alternativeName: Avoid storing passwords in the config files

qualityStandards.name: The application must not contain embedded authentication data.
